elements.text: PART ONE
SCENE 1: INT. GAMES ROOM
(FX: IT’S 1926, AND WE’RE IN THE GAMES ROOM OF A SANATORIUM ON
TOP OF A SWISS MOUNTAIN. A GRAMOPHONE PLAYS ‘THE BLACK BOTTOM’.
RESIDENTS ARE PLAYING A BOARD GAME.)
It’s your turn to play, you know.
(HE CAN’T THINK OF ANYTHING) Sorry, old chap.
Maybe you could add an “S” to something. Icicles, perhaps?
Or mouses.
Mice, Harry.
Oh yes.
I’m not as good at this as I once was.
None of us is, Swapnil. Except Mrs Kniddel.
Don’t embarrass her, Ludo.
I’1ll just put an “I” here.
FX: CLICK OF TILE
I-D? No initials, you said.
Id, Harry. It’s a bit of the mind.
The bit with all the things you don’t want to know about, old man.
Very smart.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 3
But very low-scoring.
And now, Mrs Kniddel, the board is yours.
FX: A CLICK AS A TILE ARE PLACED ON THE BOARD
(SOTTO) Oh, she’s adding something to Harry's.
(SOTTO). Ate. Ated?
FX: CLICK
(SOTTO) Mated.
FX: FOUR MORE CLICKS
Checkmated. Oh she’s good, isn’t she?
(SOTTO) And quiet. Very quiet.
All seven tiles. A “K” on a triple word score. And a fifty point bonus.
(APPLAUDING) Mrs Kniddel! Not a word spoken for eight long years! And yet...
And yet you are the board game demon of this entire mountain.
Yes, take a bow, do, dear.
(APPLAUDING) Bravo! Follow that, Harry.
I’1ll try.
FX: THE CLICK OF TILES.
There.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 4
Eh?
Howzabout that?
What does it mean?
Never heard of it.
If it’s a proper noun it’s not allowed.
. D-I-S.
‘Tar-dice.’
Means nothing to me.
It’s something you climb inside.
Oh, twaddle, Harry, this is just the WOFGOP incident all over again. I suppose TAR-DICE is a solvent used in the production of mothballs as well, is it?
It has two doors. It’s blue. Sometimes I can see it.
You're a tricksy player, Harry.
No, really.
And we don’t appreciate that. We have to stick to the rules.
But it hurts. It hurts so much. At the back of my head. In my throat. In my eyes. Stone me, sometimes, just at the edge, if don’t look directly, I can...
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 5
Harry!
Sometimes if I try to look just to the side of where I’m looking...
Stop it, Harry. That’s not the way we play round here.
It’s what we all agreed. Otherwise, who knows what would happen?
You're right. Sorry. It’s just that...
Now. What game shall we play next? Harry, you choose.
How about Consequences?
Consequences!
Fine.
Have you a pencil, Mrs Kniddel? Good. So, we begin with a man’s name. A funny one, if possible, everybody.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 6
SCENE 2: INT. CABLE CAR
(FX: A CABLE CAR CREAKS AND GRINDS ITS WAY UP THE SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN. A LOW WIND HOWLS. INSIDE, A GROGGY AND DISORIENTED
IS WAKING UP; HIS TRAVELLING COMPANION, QUEENIE
— CHEERFUL, GIRTON-EDUCATED, OUTDOORSY — IS UNCAPPING A FLASK OF SOUP.)
Cockaleeky?
(STARTING, SUDDENLY AWAKE) What-—?
Cockaleeky?
(BEFUDDLED) Soup?
(FX: UNCAPPING THE FLASK) It’s from a tin. Bought it from Lipton’s. None of your foreign muck.
No thank you. Where did the ground go?
It’s best not to look down. (FX: OPENING THE WINDOW) The air is marvellous, though, isn’t it?
Is it safe to do that?
Do what?
Pull down the window. On a cable car.
Oh, don’t be such a milquetoast. If you jump up and down at this end you can swing it about, you know.
FX: A JUMP AND AN OMINOUS CREAK
Don’t do that, please...
You’re prone to giddiness, then?
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 7
I am right now.
Well just keep looking up. At the clouds. And the mountain. What a mountain!
It’s snowing.
Well, naturally. It wouldn’t be Switzerland if it weren’t snowing.
Switzerland?
Where the nuts go to. I’1l1 shut this window, shall I?
Yes.
FX: THE WINDOW CLATTERS SHUT
Thank you.
We’re only half an hour or so from the Sanatorium.
(SOTTO) Ah! So I’m ill, then, am I?
Well, you might be, chum. I’m just going to see my old dad.
I wonder if I have a ticket somewhere? (FX: HE SEARCHES HIS POCKETS) Do you remember where I got on?
Hmmm. Not really. That’s the thing about cable cars. You jump on. You go round. You could go round and round forever, if you wanted to. Do you remember where you got on?
(STILL LOOKING IN HIS POCKETS) Not at all, Miss ...
Glasscock. Queenie Glasscock. And it’s Mrs. Thanks to a man from the Herne Hill velodrome.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 8
Oh yes?
Yes, well, it’s a sorry story. We went to Hastings for the honeymoon. He abandoned me on the esplanade. Just cycled off.
The blackguard.
. With his waxed moustache and his Sturmey-Archer internal gear hub...
(STILL SEARCHING HIS POCKETS) A blackguard’s gear hub...
Some girl on the team told me he was married already.
Who to?
To whom? To the woman who works the comptometer at Liptons. Currant eyes and a face like a smacked bottom.
Sounds like a lucky escape. (FX: SEARCHING HIS POCKETS) Oh, look, I’ve found a liquorice allsort.
Anyway, Daddy said he was a rotter. Daddy always knows.
He does?
Oh yes. Daddy’s always one step ahead of the other player.
It’s the best place to be, if you don’t want to be checkmated. (HE’S FOUND SOMETHING ELSE IN HIS POCKET) Aha! (FX: PAPER UNWRAPPED) Now what does this say?
How’s your head?
Much better. I can almost read this.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 9
Good.
How’s your father?
Much better, considering.
Considering what?
Considering that he’s quite, quite doolally.
Oh dear. Is there anything I can do?
Why, are you a doctor?
I believe so. Or at least, that’s what it says on this piece of paper.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 10
SCENE 3: INT. GAMES ROOM
(READING) Professor Moriarty... how about that, eh?
Who wrote that? He’s not really what you’d call a funny person...
Professor Moriarty met...
Queen Geraldine of the Albanians. Beside the Zuider Zee.
The Zuider-zee?
Well beggar me!
He said to her...
“See how the pomegranates shimmer in the moonlight.”
She said to hin...
“Not blooming likely!”
They were married...
In suspicious circumstances.
And the consequences were...
A monkey ate all their bananas.
FX: A GENERAL CHUCKLE OF APPROVAL.
The bananas were your work, weren’t they, Mrs Kniddel? I thought so.
Wasn’t that fun?
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 11
Well, it did keep us all alive. For another half hour.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 12
SCENE 4: INT. CABLE CAR
So you’re a Doctor.
Apparently. Is this a laundry list?
(READS) Doctor. Beige jacket. Tank top. Question mark umbrella.
Clearly me, isn’t it?
Yes. Should you be worried?
Up to a point. I’ve had amnesia before.
And how did you get over it then?
I really can’t [remember ]
(INTERRUPTING) Well of course you can’t.
But I don’t think we ought to let that concern us. I’1l behave as if I remember exactly why I’m on my way to a sanatoriun ...
Hahlbruck sanatorium...
And all the details will come flooding back.
I must say you’re taking all this very well.
When your consciousness has been jiggered about with as much as mine, you learn to...
Adapt?
Probably. Funny thing is... Switzerland. Now I know I’m suffering from memory loss, but that seems wrong to me.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 13
What do you mean?
Well, whoever I am, I’m not the sort of person who says, ‘let’s go to Switzerland.’ It just sounds wrong coming out of my mouth.
It does?
‘I say, how about a trip to Vevey?’ ‘Oh! The cantons are so lovely at this time of year!’ ‘I do love the cheese with the
holes!’ It’s just not very me, is it?
Well...
I mean, do you believe I like that sort of thing? Vevey? Cantons? I mean, do you? I didn’t even know the name of this place.
Hahlbruck. And here we are. There’s the cable car station. And there, up above it...
What’s so extraordinary about Hahlbruck sanatorium?
Well, it’s the finest recuperative centre in Davos. Tip-top for anything pulmonary.
Never heard of it.
Oh it’s famous. If you need to expectorate into a kidney dish, then Hahlbruck is the place to do it. It’s good for ennui, too. Or it used to be. Back in the good old days.
Oh yes? What happened?
Something involving the medical director and several thousand volts.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 14
Sounds more like a kill than a cure.
It snuffed out Dr Black like a thrupenny candle. I think business has been a little depressed since.
Like the patients?
Like the ones that were left behind.
Well that’s something, anyway. Something promising. An unexplained death on the top of a mountain. Something for me to get my teeth into...
(FX: THE CLUNK OF THE CABLE CAR ARRIVING AT ITS STOPPING POINT. THEN SILENCE. )
This is us.
Yes. And only us.
That’s very frustrating. No chap to open the door.
No chap to do anything. Allow me.
(FX: THE WINDOW IS ROLLED DOWN, THE DOCTOR STICKS HIS ARM THROUGH AND OPENS THE DOOR WITH THE OUTSIDE HANDLE. )
There. Who stopped the mechanism, do you think?
It must work by itself. (FX: SHE’S GATHERING UP HER LUGGAGE. ) Bring that hatbox, would you?
Yes, Mrs Glasscock. (FX: THE DOCTOR PULLS DOWN THE HATBOX. )
(CLAMBERING DOWN TO THE WOODEN PLATFORM) Watch the step.
(FX: THE GEARS SUDDENLY START UP AGAIN AND THE CARS ARE ALL IN
ONCE MORE. )
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 15
Whoa-!
Mind-! They don’t give you much time to get out, do they?
No. Which is odd. As we’re the only passengers.
Eh?
Look. Now our car has shifted you can see right down the cable. And all the other cars...
They’re empty. Quite empty.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 16
SCENE 5: INT. GAMES ROOM
No shortage of chairs. But will this work with three people?
Let’s give it a try, Ludo.
Right-ho. Down goes the needle.
(FX: A SONG TINKLES FROM THE GRAMOPHONE, THEN STOPS SUDDENLY. THERE’S A KERFUFFLE. THE NOISE OF EVERYONE SCRABBLING FOR A CHAIR. )
Cor, Mrs Kniddel, you’ve got elbows on you, aintcha?
Fair and square, Harry. You’re out.
Musical statues is more my forte.
Take away another chair. (FX: CHAIR SCRAPE) And off we go!
(FX: THE MUSIC STARTS AGAIN. UNDERNEATH THE TUNE THERE’S THE
SOUND OF A CLANGING DOORBELL. AND AGAIN. )
Hey, what’s that?
FX: MUSIC STOPS. THE BELL RINGS AGAIN.
Visitors, Ludo. My brother promised to visit this month. I wonder if...
Why don’t you answer it?
Oh no. I know that trick. Electrified door handle. Me on the hall carpet, spitting foam. No thank you, matey.
Don’t be absurd, Harry. The door handle isn’t electrified. What rot.
(FX: THE DISTANT SOUND OF THE DOCTOR RECEIVING A POWERFUL
SHOCK. A CRY OF SURPRISE FROM QUEENIE. )
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet
Must be the knocker today.
Our chums in the attic, I suppose?
Play the game, Harry.
So shouldn’t they be told? Them upstairs?
You’re right, Harry. Permit me. Pip-pip.
FX: SWAPNIL EXITS
So we have a winner. Mrs Kniddel. Again!
And there’s a prize.
Oh yes. A little tin of biscuits.
You’1ll share them, won’t you, Mrs K?
FINAL
Page 17
Capital. And when we’ve all had one, we can administer first
aid to our guests. Let’s have some music, shall we?
FX: THE RECORD STARTS AGAIN.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 18
SCENE 6: INT. OUTSIDE THE ATTIC DOOR
(FX: THROUGH A THICK OAK DOOR WE HEAR THE MUFFLED CLICK AND TICK OF CLOCKWORK MACHINERY. A DISTANT TELEPRINTER CHUGS AND GRUNTS. SWAPNIL TAPS ON THE DOOR. )
Hello? (NO RESPONSE) Can you hear me?
FX: ON OUR SIDE OF THE DOOR: ONE ELECTRIC BUZZ.
Good-oh. Thought you ought to know, chaps. Two more on the doormat. You haven’t killed them, have you? Have you?
FX: TWO BUZZES.
And is that good or bad? It’s so difficult to remember the rules. Well if you have any special instructions, just write them on a piece of paper and slide it under the [door]
FX: A PAPER IS SHOVED UNDER THE DOOR TOWARDS HIM.
. Oh, you have. (PICKS IT UP) Beige jacket. Tank top. Question mark umbrella. The Doctor, eh?
FX: BUZZ
We have to play with him again?
FX: BUZZ
So what is it this time? Let’s have a look. (FX: CRINKLE OF PAPER) Oh .. but that’1l finish him off, won’t it?
FX: PAUSE. TWO UNCERTAIN BUZZES.
You don’t sound very sure.
FX: BUZZ
Alright chaps. I’1ll see what I can do.
FX: BUZZ
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 19
Though I feel obliged to inform you that there is no Q in electrocute.
FX: ANGRY BUZZ BUZZ BUZZ
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 20
SCENE 7: EXT. AT THE FRONT DOOR/INT. HALLWAY
FX: THE FRONT DOOR OPENS
Well about time too.
Can we help you, Miss?
This man needs medical help.
Ludo here’s a doctor.
Good. Look after him, then.
Of course.
And you — are you any good at carrying things?
Not bad.
You can take my luggage inside then.
FX: HARRY SHOULDERS THE LUGGAGE.
Let’s get him in, too, shall we?
Oh yes. There’s a cosy ottoman in the hallway.
FX: THEY STRUGGLE INSIDE.
What happened to him?
It was an electric shock.
Here we are. Let’s have that cushion, Harry. And shut the door, too, there’s a good chap.
FX: THE DOCTOR LOWERED ON TO THE OTTOMAN. THE DOOR CLOSES.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 21
Some kind of static charge must have built up in the ether.
Ether? Fiddlesticks. There’s just something wrong with the wiring. And it’s hard to believe that it wasn’t done on purpose.
Oh really, Miss...
Glasscock.
(REVIVING) And it’s Mrs.
Oh. Hello. Feeling better, are we?
(JUMPING TO HIS FEET) Actually I feel rather better than I did an hour ago.
A side effect of the shock, perhaps.
I’ve had one of my funny turns, do you see? Except that I don’t really have funny turns. So I suppose I must have had one of somebody’s else’s funny turns. Wasn’t one of yours, was it?
Certainly not.
FX: SWAPNIL ENTERS.
Queenie!
Daddy! Daddy! My Daddy!
Oh Queenie, it’s so marvellous to see you. I thought once you were married...
So did I. But then I went to Hastings.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 22
What happened in Hastings, my little humdum?
The train was on time. The hotel was lovely. The towels were terribly soft.
And the weather?
It held out all week. Which is more than you can say for the marriage.
So this isn’t your husband?
I’m no blackguard.
No, this is the Doctor. He’s here for amnesia.
I’ll be the judge of that.
Oh? And who are you, exactly?
I’m the deputy medical director. Ludovic Comfort. Director, Since the sad loss of Dr Black.
Ludo, you’re a grim old stick. Doctor, my name is Swapnil Khan. You've already met my daughter. And the man holding the hatbox is Mr Harry Randall.
Pleased to meet you, Mr Randall.
Harry topped the bill at the Penge Empire. But then...
The war, you know.
I quite understand.
FX: DOOR TO GAMES ROOM OPENS AND MRS KNIDDEL ENTERS.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 23
And here’s our fourth for bridge.
Mrs Elsa Kniddel, our resident pianist.
How do you do?
(SOTTO) Mrs Kniddel has not spoken since an undisclosed incident in a rowing boat on Lake Balaton in the summer of 1919. But I assure you that she comprehends all.
I’m sure that you do, Mrs Kniddel. Are you the only patients here?
Almost. Unless you count the pair in the isolation ward. But they were brought in.. when was it, Harry?
A month ago, was it? Sorry. I feel a bit odd.
Put that hatbox down and have a seat, Harry. (FX: HARRY SITS DOWN) Tuesday week. And nobody’s seen hide nor hair of them. I suppose it must be something contagious.
They simply need rest, that’s all.
Where is the isolation ward?
In the attic.
Of course it is.
Actually it’s time I looked in on them. Would you excuse me?
Of course, Director.
FX: LUDO EXITS
Well, that’s that, then. Case almost closed.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 24
What do you mean?
(FX: HARRY MAKES AN ODD GULPING SOUND. HIS DISCOMFORT INCREASES. )
These new patients hold the key to what’s happening here. Mysterious people in attics always do. I’d bet my hat on it.
You don’t have a hat.
No. So apart from my missing hat, that leaves just one more mystery to solve.
FX: HARRY GULPS LOUDLY
Which is?
What’s the trouble with Harry?
(FX: HARRY SUFFERS A VIOLENT CONVULSION AND CRUMPLES TO THE FLOOR, FITTING. )
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 25
SCENE 8: INT. OUTSIDE THE ATTIC DOOR
FX: THE CLICK AND TICK OF MACHINERY AND TELEPRINTERS.
Open the door please. (PAUSE) Come on, just open up.
FX: BUZZ BUZZ

Don’t give me that. I’m not Swapnil. You can’t keep me out. (PAUSE) Do you know, as I was coming upstairs, I saw the cable car had started up again. I hadn’t anticipated that. (PAUSE) Do I have to break this door down? There is an axe here, you know.
(FX: THE DOOR SWISHES OPEN. THE SOUND FROM INSIDE BECOMES LOUDER. )
Thank you. I hope you’ve got a drink ready for me —
(OFF) Ludo! Ludo!
(SOTTO) What is it now? (TO SWAPNIL) Just a moment!
(NEARLY ARRIVED) It’s an emergency, Ludo!
(TO THE OCCUPANTS OF THE ATTIC) Well shut the door, then. Do you want him to see you?
FX: THE DOOR HISSES SHUT.
(ARRIVING) Ludo, it’s Harry. He needs your help.
The usual, I suppose.
Did you have that door open?
Don’t be preposterous, Swapnil. That would be an entirely illegal move.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 26
SCENE 9: INT. HALLWAY
FX: HARRY IS FITTING.
Loosen his tie. (FX: TIE UNLOOSENED.) And throw me that cushion, Mrs Kniddel.
FX: CUSHION HITS FLOOR.
Would some soup be any use?
Yes, if the object was to choke him to death.
So what’s wrong with him? Epilepsy, perhaps?
Perhaps.
(FX: LUDO AND SWAPNIL ENTER THE ROOM. THE SQUEAKY WHEEL OF
WHEELCHAIR. )
Right, we’ll take over here. Thank you so much, Doctor. Mrs
Glasscock. Park the chair there, will you, Swapnil?
This thing could do with a drop of oil.
You’ve seen this before?
Twice a week. He usually waits until after dinner, though. soon as he’s finished the nuts, over he goes.
FX: HARRY CALMS DOWN.
Oh. That looks better.
It’s alright, Harry. It’s alright.
Swapnil, would you help me lift him into the chair?
FX: THEY LIFT HIM INTO THE WHEELCHAIR.
AN
As
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 27
Now, Mrs Kniddel, you usually push, don’t you? Thank you. We’1l be back in an hour or so.
(RECOVERING) Did I do it again?
You did, Harry.
I’d like to come with you.
No need, Doctor, really.
I’d take a look out of the window if I were you. We have more visitors on the way. Go, on, look. There’s a magnificent view from the balcony.
FX: LUDO AND MRS KNIDDEL PUSH HARRY OUT THROUGH THE DOOR.
(FX: OPENING THE FRENCH WINDOWS TO THE BALCONY.) Come out and look, Doctor. He’s right.
(JOINING HIM) About what?
That little line of lights. The cable car is moving again.
I wonder who it is.
Mr Khan, where has the director taken Harry?
To the treatment room, of course.
But what kind of treatment will he receive?
About three hundred volts I believe.
What?
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 28
Or four hundred. I’m not entirely sure. I never bother to look
at the dial.
We’ll see about that.
FX: DOCTOR RUNS AWAY, SLAMMING THE DOOR BEHIND HIM.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 29
SCENE 10: INT. TREATMENT ROOM
Alright Mrs Kniddel. Tighten the straps, would you?
FX: LEATHER CUFFS BEING ATTACHED TO HARRY’S WRISTS.
It’s no good, Ludo. I remember him. Beige jacket! Question mark umbrella! He comes here every day and by teatime he’s forgotten it all. But I’1ll keep remembering him. No matter what you do to me.
I’d give the old jaw a rest, if I were you.
And the TARDIS, too. The TARDIS! The peeling paint and the flashing light!
The bone, Mrs Kniddel. Bite on that, please, Harry.
(FX: THE BONE IS STUFFED INTO HARRY’S MOUTH. LUDO POWERS UP THE MACHINE. )
Stand back from the table, Mrs Kniddel.
And there was another man, too. A smiling man.
FX: THE DOCTOR BURSTS THROUGH THE DOOR.
Stop this right now, Director!
First dose coming now.
Turn off the machine!
Did I ask for a second opinion, Doctor?
(FX: LUDO THROWS THE SWITCH. THE DULL CRACKLE OF ELECTRICITY.
GURNING AND THRASHING. )
Turn it off! You’1l kill him!
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 30
Stand back, Doctor! For your own safety.
(FX: THE SHRILL WHINE OF THE SONIC SCREWDRIVER. A SHOWER OF SPARKS. THE CLUNK AND THUD OF A 1920S ECT MACHINE BEING REDUCED TO SCRAP. THE SMOKE CLEARS. )
What was that device?
I haven’t the faintest idea. I just found it in my pocket and Switched it on. Looks a bit like... one of those things you use to check the pressure in tyres...
Doctor — you have no idea what you’ve done, have you?
I simply made a medical intervention.
(IN SHOCK) I say I say I Say...
You’ve destroyed our one hope of survival.
Don’t be ridiculous.
Where do sick bees go?
I haven’t done anything of the kind.
I don’t know, where do sick bees go?
All I did was prevent you causing irreparable damage to your patient’s brain.
To the wasp-ital.
This is quite beyond repair.
That was the idea.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 31
My mother in law is a wooden shoe woman. Wooden shoe like to lend me this, wooden shoe like to lend me that?
You just don’t know when to stop, do you? You just don’t know when to let things alone.
Perhaps I haven’t stopped yet. I may have lost my grip on precisely who I am, but saving people from electrocution — that feels very me. So does — oh, let me think — going up to the attic, perhaps?
No, Doctor. I can’t let you do that.
Try stopping me!
FX: THE DOCTOR RUNS THROUGH THE DOOR.
Met my wife in the tunnel of love. She was digging it.
Mrs Kniddel. Go to my study and fetch a phial of number 78 and a cloth. Now, please.
FX: SHE EXITS.
You’ve been a lovely audience. Much better than last week!
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 32
SCENE 11: INT. CABLE CAR
(FX: THE CAR IS CREAKING UPWARDS. IT NOW CONTAINS LOLA LUNA,
DOYENNE OF THE WEIMAR CABARET CIRCUIT, AND HERBERT RANDALL, HARRY’S TWIN BROTHER. LOLA HAS A TUBE INSERTED INTO
LUNGS, THROUGH WHICH SHE CAN BREATHE — AND THEREFORE ALSO WHISTLE. )
The lights of the Hahlbruck sanatorium. Like a string of diamonds on the neck of the mountain. Herbert!
(EATING) Eh?
Like a string of diamonds on the neck of the mountain, darling.
Absolutely. What is this meat?
Pastrami, Herbert, pastrami.
Ain't a patch on the king’s own ham.
Your brother’s up there, Herbert.
What’s left of him, the poor soul.
And the Doctor is there, too. He was a little ahead of us today. He’ll already have his fingers into everything.
If you need a hero, then the Doctor’s your man.
Unfortunately that is precisely what we don’t need. But how can we stop him this time?
We've done it before. Cable car. Sanatorium. Electricity. You know how it goes.
Yes, but every round gets trickier and trickier. And nobody roots for us. They all love him so much.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 33
SINGS, MUSIC HALL STYLE.
Who’s welcomed warmly everywhere? By stalwart men and ladies fair? Who to the children all is dear? The Doctor!
Who gives the monsters such a shock? Who likes a sidekick in a frock?
Who foiled the Gods of Ragnarok?
The Doctor!
Do the whistle, girl. The old pneumothoracic whistle!
(FX: THE FOLLOWING DUET HAS A THIRD ELEMENT — A DEEP BUT
WHISTLE THROUGH LOLA’S TUBE. )
He travels through the web of time He roots out tyranny and crime We’1ll cut him down before his prime! The Doctor!
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 34
SCENE 12: INT. OUTSIDE THE ATTIC DOOR
FX: LUDO AND BANGING UP THE STAIRS.
Doctor! Doctor, stop what you’re doing.
(FX: THE SONIC SCREWDRIVER IS WHIRRING AWAY AT THE LOCK OF THE
DOOR, FROM BEHIND WHICH THERE COMES THE CUSTOMARY CLICKING AND TICKING. )
You're a little wonder, aren’t you? I’m keeping you! Look at this, Ludo. It can burn through wood. I’1l soon have this lock out.

HARRY: And the TARDIS, too. The TARDIS! The peeling paint and the flashing light!
LUDO: The bone, Mrs Kniddel. Bite on that, please, Harry.
LUDO: (FX: THE BONE IS STUFFED INTO HARRY’S MOUTH. LUDO POWERS UP THE MACHINE. )
LUDO: Stand back from the table, Mrs Kniddel.
HARRY: And there was another man, too. A smiling man.
DOCTOR: Stop this right now, Director!
LUDO: First dose coming now.
DOCTOR: Turn off the machine!
LUDO: Did I ask for a second opinion, Doctor?
LUDO: (FX: LUDO THROWS THE SWITCH. THE DULL CRACKLE OF ELECTRICITY.
HARRY: GURNING AND THRASHING. )
DOCTOR: Turn it off! You’1l kill him!
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 30
LUDO: Stand back, Doctor! For your own safety.
LUDO: (FX: THE SHRILL WHINE OF THE SONIC SCREWDRIVER. A SHOWER OF SPARKS. THE CLUNK AND THUD OF A 1920S ECT MACHINE BEING REDUCED TO SCRAP. THE SMOKE CLEARS. )
LUDO: What was that device?
DOCTOR: I haven’t the faintest idea. I just found it in my pocket and Switched it on. Looks a bit like... one of those things you use to check the pressure in tyres...
LUDO: Doctor — you have no idea what you’ve done, have you?
DOCTOR: I simply made a medical intervention.
HARRY: (IN SHOCK) I say I say I Say...
LUDO: You’ve destroyed our one hope of survival.
DOCTOR: Don’t be ridiculous.
HARRY: Where do sick bees go?
DOCTOR: I haven’t done anything of the kind.
HARRY: I don’t know, where do sick bees go?
DOCTOR: All I did was prevent you causing irreparable damage to your patient’s brain.
HARRY: To the wasp-ital.
LUDO: This is quite beyond repair.
DOCTOR: That was the idea.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 31
HARRY: My mother in law is a wooden shoe woman. Wooden shoe like to lend me this, wooden shoe like to lend me that?
LUDO: You just don’t know when to stop, do you? You just don’t know when to let things alone.
DOCTOR: Perhaps I haven’t stopped yet. I may have lost my grip on precisely who I am, but saving people from electrocution — that feels very me. So does — oh, let me think — going up to the attic, perhaps?
LUDO: No, Doctor. I can’t let you do that.
DOCTOR: Try stopping me!
HARRY: Met my wife in the tunnel of love. She was digging it.
LUDO: Mrs Kniddel. Go to my study and fetch a phial of number 78 and a cloth. Now, please.
HARRY: You’ve been a lovely audience. Much better than last week!
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 32
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 11: INT. CABLE CAR
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: THE CAR IS CREAKING UPWARDS. IT NOW CONTAINS LOLA LUNA,
FORMER: DOYENNE OF THE WEIMAR CABARET CIRCUIT, AND HERBERT RANDALL, HARRY’S TWIN BROTHER. LOLA HAS A TUBE INSERTED INTO
HER: LUNGS, THROUGH WHICH SHE CAN BREATHE — AND THEREFORE ALSO WHISTLE. )
LOLA: The lights of the Hahlbruck sanatorium. Like a string of diamonds on the neck of the mountain. Herbert!
HERBERT: (EATING) Eh?
LOLA: Like a string of diamonds on the neck of the mountain, darling.
HERBERT: Absolutely. What is this meat?
LOLA: Pastrami, Herbert, pastrami.
HERBERT: Ain't a patch on the king’s own ham.
LOLA: Your brother’s up there, Herbert.
HERBERT: What’s left of him, the poor soul.
LOLA: And the Doctor is there, too. He was a little ahead of us today. He’ll already have his fingers into everything.
HERBERT: If you need a hero, then the Doctor’s your man.
LOLA: Unfortunately that is precisely what we don’t need. But how can we stop him this time?
HERBERT: We've done it before. Cable car. Sanatorium. Electricity. You know how it goes.
LOLA: Yes, but every round gets trickier and trickier. And nobody roots for us. They all love him so much.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 33
HERBERT: Who’s welcomed warmly everywhere? By stalwart men and ladies fair? Who to the children all is dear? The Doctor!
LOLA: Who gives the monsters such a shock? Who likes a sidekick in a frock?
LOLA: Who foiled the Gods of Ragnarok?
LOLA: The Doctor!
HERBERT: Do the whistle, girl. The old pneumothoracic whistle!
HERBERT: (FX: THE FOLLOWING DUET HAS A THIRD ELEMENT — A DEEP BUT
TUNEFUL: WHISTLE THROUGH LOLA’S TUBE. )
HERBERT AND LOLA: He travels through the web of time He roots out tyranny and crime We’1ll cut him down before his prime! The Doctor!
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 34
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 12: INT. OUTSIDE THE ATTIC DOOR
LUDO: Doctor! Doctor, stop what you’re doing.
LUDO: (FX: THE SONIC SCREWDRIVER IS WHIRRING AWAY AT THE LOCK OF THE
ATTIC: DOOR, FROM BEHIND WHICH THERE COMES THE CUSTOMARY CLICKING AND TICKING. )
DOCTOR: You're a little wonder, aren’t you? I’m keeping you! Look at this, Ludo. It can burn through wood. I’1l soon have this lock out.
LUDO: Doctor, stand back from that door. My patients. The contagion.
DOCTOR: I’m working on the right door, I hope. What I want is behind here, isn’t it?
LUDO: You’ve already done so much damage.
DOCTOR: Mysteries must be solved. Locked doors must be unlocked. There’s something interesting behind here and I’m going in...
LUDO: But Doctor...
DOCTOR: I’m not waiting for the bodies to start piling up. I’m going straight to the top this time.
DOCTOR: Hey presto.
LUDO: You didn’t open that door. They did.
DOCTOR: Who?
LUDO: Don’t go in there, Doctor. For the sake of this mountain and everybody on it. Don’t go in there.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 35
DOCTOR: I’m sorry, Ludo. It’s the only way.
LUDO: You’1l regret it, Doctor!
LUDO: (HALFWAY THROUGH LUDO’S NEXT LINE THE DOOR HISSES SHUT, MUFFLING THE REST OF HIS WORDS — WE ARE NOW IN THE ISOLATION WARD WITH THE DOCTOR. )
DOCTOR: Clockwork. How quaint. Did you choose the décor yourself?
DOCTOR: And a robot, too. Is he yours? (PAUSE) I’m surprised you don’t want to talk. Because you both look terribly familiar. We've certainly met before. I can’t place you. But I know you. I know both of you...
HEX: [AS BOBO] (STRANGELY POSH, BUT IT’S HIM) You might know us...
ACE: [AS BUNTY] (OH SO POSH) But who are you — you funny little man?
ACE: END OF PART ONE
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 36

elements.text: PART TWO
SCENE CONTINUES:
SCENE 13: INT. THE ATTIC
I’m the Doctor.
[AS BUNTY] Oh yes?
[AS BOBO] That’s not a name, old chap, it’s a title.
It’s an honorific.
[AS BUNTY] That’s.. terrific.
And who are you, exactly?
[AS BUNTY] We’re here incognito, isn’t that so, darling?
[AS BOBO] Absolutely, Bunty.
Bunty? That’s a funny sort of name, isn’t it? It’s a little comic.
[AS BUNTY] If you say so, old man.
I do, old man. And what’s his name?
[AS BUNTY] He’s Bobo.
Bobo? Bobo and Bunty? (LAUGHS UPROARIOUSLY. )
[AS BUNTY] I think you’re beastly to laugh. We’re not very well, do you see? That’s why we’re up here in the isolation ward.
(FROM OUTSIDE THE DOOR) Hello in there!
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 37
[AS BOBO] Yes, we’re sick. Very sick.
There’s a doctor out there who wants your attention. Unless you’d prefer a second opinion from me.
(OUTSIDE) Hello! Just to say that if you’d like me to help you out, I am equipped. Mrs Kniddel’s with me too.
[AS BUNTY] Alright, let him in.
[AS BOBO] What about Mrs Kniddel?
[AS BUNTY] Her too.
[AS BOBO] Are you sure about that?
[AS BUNTY] I think we can trust her to keep a secret.
FX: A SWITCH IS THROWN. THE DOOR HISSES OPEN.
Thank you. Everything tickety-boo in here? You look as if you’ve reached a kind of social impasse.
[AS BUNTY] Get us out of it then, Ludo.
[AS BOBO] Doctor, may I present the Honourable Mr Stetterton and his wife Bunty.
Stetterton! This gets better and better.
[AS BOBO] Shush. Not so loud. We’re not really here. We don’t want to be all over the gossip magazines.
That’s why they’re in the attic, Doctor. Far away from the prying eyes of the Tatler and the Bystander.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 38
Now this is all very odd. I never read the Tatler unless I’m at the dentist. And I’ve not been to the dentist since 1881. What year is it now?
[AS BUNTY] 1926.

Well that’s that. But you know, I’m sure I’ve heard those names before. Bunty and Bobo Stetterton. And I know your faces, too. But your faces and your names don’t go together. You’re not who you think you are.
[AS BOBO] We’re not who we think we are?

Perhaps I’m not who I think I am. Perhaps none of us is. Or perhaps you don’t really think you are who you say you are. Perhaps... (A MOMENT OF SURPRISE AS LUDO MUFFLES HIS MOUTH WITH A CHLOROFORM-SOAKED RAG.) (MUFFLED BY LUDO) .. that smells like chloroform on your handkerchiet...
[AS BOBO] I’m sorry?
(CLEAR AGAIN) I said, that smells like chloroform on your handkerchief, Ludo.
Yes, it is.
Now, what was I saying? Oh yes — where have my knees gone?
FX: THE DOCTOR COLLAPSES TO THE FLOOR.
(BACK TO HER NORMAL SELF) Cheers, Ludo. I thought he’d never stop.
Usually he struggles more than that.
(ALSO BACK TO NORMAL) We can’t keep doing this to him. His biochemistry isn’t like ours. It’s not having the right effect.
It’s that or nothing, now. He’s destroyed the ECT machine.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 39
It’s just one more night and one more day, Ludo.
FX: DOORBELL RINGS DISTANTLY
That’1l be Lola and the other Randall twin.
Midnight tomorrow and we’1ll all be back home in our own beds.
I hope you’re right.
We are, Ludo. I promise you, mate, it’1ll all look better by breakfast.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 40
SCENE 14: INT. BREAKFAST ROOM
FX: FADE UP.
Good morning, Herbert. How did you sleep?
Well I just put my head down on the pillow and shut my eyes.
Me too, meine honigblenchen.
This would be the breakfast room, I suppose?
The presence of breakfast would suggest so.
Marvellous spread, innit? What do you fancy?
See what the boys in the backroom will have, and tell them I’m having the same.
That’1ll be a cup of coffee, then, will it?
Jah, bitte.
FX: HARRY POURING COFFEE. CLINK OF A CUP. SWAPNIL ARRIVES.
(ARRIVING) Good morning!
(SOTTO) The chess player.
You must be the new arrivals. Who sorted you out last night?
The director. And a big-boned taciturn Hungarian lady with a leather eye patch.
Mrs Kniddel.
That’s the bird.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 41
We should introduce ourselves.
Well we know who you are. You’re the spit of him. Herbert Randall, I presume? Harry’s brother? The other half of the Randall Twins, the serio-comic funambulists?
On the nose. Where is he, by the way?
Harry? In his room. He had a rough old night of it.
Take him up some breakfast, Harry. Here.(PILING FOOD ON TO A PLATE.) Bacon, chanterelles — and how do you call this?
Bubble and squeak.
Jah, bubble und squeak.
And you, madam, are?

This is Miss Lola Luna. Doyenne of the Weimar cabaret circuit. You ain’t nobody in Berlin until she’s stuck a fishnet leg on your table in the whisky bar and barked something seductive into your earhole. She don’t sing quite so often, now though, owing to the pneumothoracic tube poking out of her chest.
Ach, nein, it is nothing. A little pipe to ease the pressure on my lungs. That is all. On a good day I can whistle a tune through it. (SHE WHISTLES.) Intriguing, no?
Even so, I’m terribly sorry to hear you’ve been unwell, Miss Luna.
Oh, drop it, Swapnil. You know perfectly well who I am. It’s only the Doctor who doesn’t know. Where is he, by the way?
He’s sleeping something off, too, I believe.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 42
SCENE 15: INT. DOCTOR’S ROOM
FX: TAPPING ON DOOR
(FROM OUTSIDE) Doctor?
Hmm?
(FROM OUTSIDE) Are you decent?
I don’t know.
FX: QUEENIE ENTERS
Question-mark pyjamas, eh? Are they yours?
Never seen them before in my life.
Well consider yourself fortunate. They didn’t supply me with anything. And the noise kept me up all night.
What noise?
Rats, I imagine. How do you feel?
Some of the cobwebs have been blown away.
You’re seeing things more clearly, then?
I get knocked down, but I get up again. And every time they knock me down — I feel a little stronger. And I know a little more.
(FX: A SCUFFLE FROM BEHIND THE WAINSCOT. A WOODEN VENTRILOQUIST’S DUMMY IS SCUTTERING THROUGH THE WALLSPACE. )
That noise again.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 43
(SCEPTICAL) Rats in the wainscot, you say?
I admit, it sounds like something [bigger —]
(OUTSIDE THE DOOR) Doctor?
Just a moment!
(OUTSIDE) Time to get up, now.
I’1l hide under the bed.
FX: QUEENIE DIVES UNDER.
I don’t think that’s a very good [idea]
FX: LUDO OPENS THE DOOR
Morning.
Feeling yourself, Doctor?
Much better, Doctor... what is your name again?
Ludovic Comfort. I’m...
I know who you are. You’re the man who stepped into Dr Black’s shoes. While they were still sizzling.
FX: A DISTANT GONG
Breakfast. Excellent. I could eat your weight in muesli.
Breakfast was hours ago, Doctor. You’re being summoned for the morning run.
The morning what?
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 44
A constitutional perambulation around the girdle of the mountain. Something to get the old ticker pounding.
Is it obligatory?
For patients, yes. I’ve brought your running shoes. Mind the spikes as you put them on. Oh, I’ve brought a pair for you, too, Mrs Glasscock. Shall I just slide them under the bed?
(FROM UNDER THE BED) Much obliged, director.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 45
SCENE 16: INT. HARRY’S ROOM
FX: A BRISK KNOCK, A DOOR OPENS.
Harry? I’ve some breakfast for you, old fellow.
There once was a bishop of Birmingham, who — err...
Shall I put it on your bedside table?
FX: TRAY CLATTERS.
What did he do, that bishop of Birmingham?
We had the Purity League down on us when you recited that at the Bradford Alhambra.
Why am I in bed?
You’1l be right as rain soon enough. We all will.
I’m so tired, Herbie. I’ve not felt like this since...
Try not to think about it. Have a drink of water.

At Wipers, Herbert, you sometimes had your water in a petrol can. Do you remember me telling you about Billy McVeigh? Sapper in the Royal Engineers. He could tell what kind of petrol had been in the can just from drinking the water.
Harry, you know what’s coming, don’t you?
Ludo put me in the machine again. For talking about that blue box. Gave me the full whack. That’s how they’ve been doing it Harry. To stop us remembering.
Never fear, Harry. The mist is clearing. And then it’1ll be you and me together. Over the top. Like it should have been in France.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 46
SCENE 17: INT. THE ATTIC
[AS BUNTY] In Herefordshire, Hertfordshire and Hampshire Hurricanes Hardly Ever Happen.
Oh what’s the use? He recognised us, didn’t he? He knew who we were.
No way. When the Professor’s onto something, his nostrils flare and his eyebrows knit. Never happened last night.
I hate this. Lying to him. Manipulating him.
Yeah? Well he’s done it enough to us, hasn’t he? Putting us through the mangler. Setting us up.
He just seems like a lost old guy. Like the sort who used to wander into A&E with their stuff in placky bags.
Don’t start feeling sorry for him, Hex. It doesn’t help.
I just don’t like it, that’s all. It’s nasty.
It’s necessary.
You’re enjoying this, aren’t you?
FX: THE ROBOT WHIRRS AND STUTTERS.
What does the robot want?
They’re outside.
Who?
The Doctor and Queenie. And Lola. And Mrs Kniddel. Look on his little screen.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 47
What are they doing?
About half a mile an hour.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 48
SCENE 18: EXT. THE MOUNTAIN
(FX: THE DOCTOR, QUEENIE, LOLA AND MRS KNIDDEL ARE HUFFING AND
THROUGH THE SNOW. )
Hup! Hup! Hup! That’s right, let me see those knees!
Miss Luna!
How do you find the pace, Mrs Glasscock?
Madam, I have bicycled the London to Brighton with only a brief pause in Croydon for macaroons and sarsaparilla.
Bravo, Mrs Glasscock! Mrs Kniddel? Wunderbar! Doctor!
Eh?
Keeping up?
Just about. In fact, I’ve an idea.
FX: THE DOCTOR BREAKS AWAY FROM THE GROUP.
Doctor, where are you going?
Care to run with me for a bit, Queenie?
Why not? (CALLING TO LOLA) The town is this way, I suppose?
(OFF) That’s right. But it’s a dull little place. Boring, you know.
I could cope with a little boredom. What I can’t cope with is another electric shock. Come on, Queenie.
THEY JOG TOGETHER
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 49
Right behind you, Doctor. Don’t see the point in running if you’re not going anywhere.
Running away from something, I can understand that. Do it all the time. Running towards something, that has its appeals, too. But running round in circles?
Mind you, sometimes the last thing you want is to reach the end. The end can be a dangerous place to be.
I feel like a rat in a maze, Queenie. Every time I come within sniffing distance of a bit of cheese, someone clobbers me.
Or electrifies you.
Or whacks a shot of morphine into my bloodstream. Do people really come here to recuperate? This isn’t happening to you, too, is it Queenie?
No. Only you. Perhaps you deserve it, Doctor. Men are such beasts.
Or perhaps someone is protecting you. Perhaps you have the get out of jail free card. Or won second prize in a beauty contest.
What do you mean?
Maybe I’m not a rat. Maybe I’m a dog. Or a top hat.
Or a cuckoo clock? Oodles of those round here.
Games, Queenie, games. Thing is, I’m usually very good at them.
Not as good as my old dad, I'd wager.
Swapnil?
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 50

He spent his youth in Rawalpindi. All he had was a chess set, two linen suits and his wits. He went from hill station to hill station, playing the memsahibs every day. He never went hungry. Never slept in a bed without a feather pillow.
Maybe we’re running in the wrong direction, then. Let’s go and see him.
Daddy, you mean?
Yes. Come on, they’ve given us the shoes — let’s put them to some use. (SLIPPING) Wooooaaaah! (TUMBLING) Queenie!
Doctor!
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 51
SCENE 19: INT. THE ATTIC
(FX: OVER ROBOT’S SCREEN) Doctor, are you alright-?
Oh, the Doctor’s hit the deck.
Jogged too far, has he?
He slipped on something. A patch of ice, I suppose.
FX: FURIOUS CLOCKWORK CHUNTERING.
No, something else. Something that was here before we arrived.
Oh well, maybe a smack on the head will buy us a bit more time.
FX: THE MACHINE CHUNTERS.
Oh my God. Look at this.
He’s going to get a bit more than a smack on the head, then. Oh well. They’ve got their running shoes on, haven’t they?
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 52
SCENE 20: EXT. THE MOUNTAIN
Doctor! Let me help you up.
FX: SHE DOES SO.
What was it this time?
No wonder you slipped.
What is it?
A square cut into the ground. Like glass. With writing on it.
(READING) ‘You cause... something... miss.’ Must be a message for you. I’m not a Miss.
Neither am I, Doctor. Let’s find out what the missing word is.
(FX: SHE RUBS AWAY AT THE LETTERS. A DISTANT RUMBLE BUILDS
IT BECOMES A THUNDEROUS ROAR. )
Oh. (READING) ‘You cause an avalanche, miss.’
Oh dear. They’re wrong about your marital status, but...
FX: THE ROAR OF THE AVALANCHE.
Do you think we can outrun it?
We’ll have to try. Come on!
FX: THEY BEGIN TO RUN; THE AVALANCHE RUMBLES AND ROARS.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 53
SCENE 21: EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE MOUNTAIN
FX: DISTANT AVALANCHE RUMBLE

Have you seen many avalanches at Hahlbruck, Mrs Kniddel? (PAUSE) It’s just that I’ve never seen one do that before. Move like that. It’s like a great gross serpent. A tentacle. Unusual, jah? (PAUSE) As is the fact that it’s only following the Doctor. Perhaps this is how it all ends, Mrs Kniddel. Perhaps this is how we all get back home.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 54
SCENE 22: EXT. THE MOUNTAIN
(FX: AVALANCHE CLOSING IN; QUEENIE AND THE DOCTOR RUNNING FOR THEIR LIVES. )
If the girls at the velodrome could see me now! Tally-ho!
Queenie, this avalanche could kill us both! Stop enjoying yourself!
Sorry, Doctor! You’re quite right! Do we stand a chance, do you think?
I think you do.
What do you mean?
That’s not an ordinary avalanche. Watch what happens when I move away from you.
FX: HE CHANGES DIRECTION. THE AVALANCHE SOUND CHANGES TOO.
Heavens! It’s following you, Doctor!
You cause an avalanche. Miss a turn. I landed on that square. I’m being penalised.
Oh I see! Like snakes and ladders. So what you need is a change of luck. Another throw. Or — (SUDDENLY VERY EXCITED) — another
square to land on!
Yes. So I’d just run in the opposite direction if I were you.
No, look, there — another square to land on! By that ridge!
Queenie, you’re brilliant!
FX: THEY RUN TOWARDS IT AND STOP. AVALANCHE THUNDERS CLOSER.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 55
Oh, it’s blank!
No, the letters are just iced over. (GETS OUT SONIC SCREWDRIVER.) Maybe I can melt it with this. (FX: SONIC SCREWDRIVER. )
Hurry up!
No, Queenie, you hurry up. Get out of here, now. Go on, get out!
Doctor!
Run! Just run!
(FX: SHE RUNS. THE DOCTOR WORKS WITH THE SCREWDRIVER. THE
BUILDS TO A CRESCENDO. SCREWDRIVER SWITCHED OFF. )
Now, let’s see what this is. Oh, now that’s just ridiculous! How can anybody possibly do that?
FX: THE AVALANCHE ARRIVES AND SWALLOWS HIM
Aaaaaarrrrghhh!
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 56
SCENE 23: INT. THE ATTIC
FX: AVALANCHE RUMBLES OVER ROBOT’S SCREEN
Ace! He’s gone. He’s gone under. What are we going to do now?
I wouldn’t worry too much, Hex.
What — now he’s dead all our troubles are over?
Look at the place where he slipped. It’s on the robot’s screen. You can read what it says.
(READING) ‘You cause an avalanche. Miss a turn.’
Doesn’t sound very terminal, does it?
So where’s he gone? Which channel is it?
Twiddle his knobs.
(FX: CHANGING CHANNELS ON THE ROBOT’S CHEST TV. LIVE RELAY FROM THE MOUNTAIN. )
(FROM TV SPEAKER) Doctor! Doctor are you alright?
There’s Queenie. Nothing wrong with her.
(FX: CLICK TO A NEW CHANNEL. RELAY FROM DOCTOR. ROAR OF THE AVALANCHE. )
(FROM SPEAKER) Whoooah!
Blimey.
You’ve been with the Doctor for a while. Ever seen him do that before?
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 57
Never had him down as a surfer, no.
But where’s it carrying him?
At a guess — through the ballroom window.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 58
SCENE 24: INT. BALLROOM
(FX: THE ROAR OF THE AVALANCHE. SMASHING GLASS AND SPLINTERING WOOD. THE DOCTOR, SURFING ON THE DETACHED BOARD-GAME SQUARE, IS
THROUGH THE FRENCH WINDOWS ON A WAVE OF SNOW. HE
AS HE SAILS THROUGH THE AIR AND LANDS ON A CHAISE LONGUE,
COLLAPSES UNDERNEATH HIM. )
Hello again, Doctor.
(GROGGY) Did you see what just happened?
Harry, Herbert, help the man to his feet. Brush the snow from his coat.(FX: HARRY AND HERBERT LIFT THE DOCTOR UP AND BRUSH
DOWN.) And the broken glass, yes. What a mess.
You must be a professional, Doctor! Stunt like that.
Is my head still attached to my neck?
Herbert and I once worked out a trick whereby we were catapulted trough some French windows on to a chaise longue. But it always went wrong during the last move. Didn’t it, Harry?
We should have put the chaise on castors, Herbie.
I unscrewed the ground beneath my feet. Only it wasn’t the ground. It was a wooden board.
This wooden board. Sledging, would you call that?
FX: SWAPNIL PICKS UP THE WOODEN BOARD
Snowboarding, I'd say.
There’s writing on it.
(READING) ‘You ride down the mountain on a wave of snow. Move on two spaces.’
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL)
So where have I landed, exactly?
This is the ballroom, Doctor. Well, it used to be. Swapnil requisitioned it.
And redecorated it?
Yes, Doctor. All my own work. What do you think?
It’s very .. modern.
You've turned the room into a gigantic chessboard.
Not much dancing goes on here anymore.
Page
Until
Who’s your opponent, Swapnil. Who do you play against?
Myself. The others here, they’re not chess people. gin rummy. And checkers.
What’s wrong with gin rummy?

QUEENIE: (FX: OVER ROBOT’S SCREEN) Doctor, are you alright-?
HEX: Oh, the Doctor’s hit the deck.
ACE: Jogged too far, has he?
HEX: He slipped on something. A patch of ice, I suppose.
ACE: No, something else. Something that was here before we arrived.
HEX: Oh well, maybe a smack on the head will buy us a bit more time.
HEX: Oh my God. Look at this.
ACE: He’s going to get a bit more than a smack on the head, then. Oh well. They’ve got their running shoes on, haven’t they?
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 52
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 20: EXT. THE MOUNTAIN
QUEENIE: Doctor! Let me help you up.
DOCTOR: What was it this time?
QUEENIE: No wonder you slipped.
DOCTOR: What is it?
QUEENIE: A square cut into the ground. Like glass. With writing on it.
DOCTOR: (READING) ‘You cause... something... miss.’ Must be a message for you. I’m not a Miss.
QUEENIE: Neither am I, Doctor. Let’s find out what the missing word is.
QUEENIE: (FX: SHE RUBS AWAY AT THE LETTERS. A DISTANT RUMBLE BUILDS
UNTIL: IT BECOMES A THUNDEROUS ROAR. )
QUEENIE: Oh. (READING) ‘You cause an avalanche, miss.’
DOCTOR: Oh dear. They’re wrong about your marital status, but...
QUEENIE: Do you think we can outrun it?
DOCTOR: We’ll have to try. Come on!
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 53
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 21: EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE MOUNTAIN
LOLA: Have you seen many avalanches at Hahlbruck, Mrs Kniddel? (PAUSE) It’s just that I’ve never seen one do that before. Move like that. It’s like a great gross serpent. A tentacle. Unusual, jah? (PAUSE) As is the fact that it’s only following the Doctor. Perhaps this is how it all ends, Mrs Kniddel. Perhaps this is how we all get back home.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 54
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 22: EXT. THE MOUNTAIN
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: AVALANCHE CLOSING IN; QUEENIE AND THE DOCTOR RUNNING FOR THEIR LIVES. )
QUEENIE: If the girls at the velodrome could see me now! Tally-ho!
DOCTOR: Queenie, this avalanche could kill us both! Stop enjoying yourself!
QUEENIE: Sorry, Doctor! You’re quite right! Do we stand a chance, do you think?
DOCTOR: I think you do.
QUEENIE: What do you mean?
DOCTOR: That’s not an ordinary avalanche. Watch what happens when I move away from you.
QUEENIE: Heavens! It’s following you, Doctor!
DOCTOR: You cause an avalanche. Miss a turn. I landed on that square. I’m being penalised.
QUEENIE: Oh I see! Like snakes and ladders. So what you need is a change of luck. Another throw. Or — (SUDDENLY VERY EXCITED) — another
QUEENIE: square to land on!
DOCTOR: Yes. So I’d just run in the opposite direction if I were you.
QUEENIE: No, look, there — another square to land on! By that ridge!
DOCTOR: Queenie, you’re brilliant!
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 55
QUEENIE: Oh, it’s blank!
DOCTOR: No, the letters are just iced over. (GETS OUT SONIC SCREWDRIVER.) Maybe I can melt it with this. (FX: SONIC SCREWDRIVER. )
QUEENIE: Hurry up!
DOCTOR: No, Queenie, you hurry up. Get out of here, now. Go on, get out!
QUEENIE: Doctor!
DOCTOR: Run! Just run!
DOCTOR: (FX: SHE RUNS. THE DOCTOR WORKS WITH THE SCREWDRIVER. THE
AVALANCHE: BUILDS TO A CRESCENDO. SCREWDRIVER SWITCHED OFF. )
DOCTOR: Now, let’s see what this is. Oh, now that’s just ridiculous! How can anybody possibly do that?
DOCTOR: Aaaaaarrrrghhh!
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 56
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 23: INT. THE ATTIC
HEX: Ace! He’s gone. He’s gone under. What are we going to do now?
ACE: I wouldn’t worry too much, Hex.
HEX: What — now he’s dead all our troubles are over?
ACE: Look at the place where he slipped. It’s on the robot’s screen. You can read what it says.
HEX: (READING) ‘You cause an avalanche. Miss a turn.’
ACE: Doesn’t sound very terminal, does it?
HEX: So where’s he gone? Which channel is it?
ACE: Twiddle his knobs.
ACE: (FX: CHANGING CHANNELS ON THE ROBOT’S CHEST TV. LIVE RELAY FROM THE MOUNTAIN. )
QUEENIE: (FROM TV SPEAKER) Doctor! Doctor are you alright?
ACE: There’s Queenie. Nothing wrong with her.
ACE: (FX: CLICK TO A NEW CHANNEL. RELAY FROM DOCTOR. ROAR OF THE AVALANCHE. )
DOCTOR: (FROM SPEAKER) Whoooah!
ACE: Blimey.
HEX: You’ve been with the Doctor for a while. Ever seen him do that before?
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 57
ACE: Never had him down as a surfer, no.
HEX: But where’s it carrying him?
ACE: At a guess — through the ballroom window.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 58
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 24: INT. BALLROOM
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: THE ROAR OF THE AVALANCHE. SMASHING GLASS AND SPLINTERING WOOD. THE DOCTOR, SURFING ON THE DETACHED BOARD-GAME SQUARE, IS
PROPELLED: THROUGH THE FRENCH WINDOWS ON A WAVE OF SNOW. HE
YELLS: AS HE SAILS THROUGH THE AIR AND LANDS ON A CHAISE LONGUE,
WHICH: COLLAPSES UNDERNEATH HIM. )
SWAPNIL: Hello again, Doctor.
DOCTOR: (GROGGY) Did you see what just happened?
SWAPNIL: Harry, Herbert, help the man to his feet. Brush the snow from his coat.(FX: HARRY AND HERBERT LIFT THE DOCTOR UP AND BRUSH
HIM: DOWN.) And the broken glass, yes. What a mess.
HARRY: You must be a professional, Doctor! Stunt like that.
DOCTOR: Is my head still attached to my neck?
HERBERT: Herbert and I once worked out a trick whereby we were catapulted trough some French windows on to a chaise longue. But it always went wrong during the last move. Didn’t it, Harry?
HARRY: We should have put the chaise on castors, Herbie.
DOCTOR: I unscrewed the ground beneath my feet. Only it wasn’t the ground. It was a wooden board.
SWAPNIL: This wooden board. Sledging, would you call that?
DOCTOR: Snowboarding, I'd say.
HARRY: There’s writing on it.
HERBERT: (READING) ‘You ride down the mountain on a wave of snow. Move on two spaces.’
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL)
DOCTOR: So where have I landed, exactly?
HARRY: This is the ballroom, Doctor. Well, it used to be. Swapnil requisitioned it.
DOCTOR: And redecorated it?
SWAPNIL: Yes, Doctor. All my own work. What do you think?
DOCTOR: It’s very .. modern.
HERBERT: You've turned the room into a gigantic chessboard.
SWAPNIL: Not much dancing goes on here anymore.
DOCTOR: Page
DOCTOR: Until
DOCTOR: Who’s your opponent, Swapnil. Who do you play against?
SWAPNIL: Myself. The others here, they’re not chess people. gin rummy. And checkers.
HARRY: What’s wrong with gin rummy?
DOCTOR: What happened to the floorboards?
SWAPNIL: 59
SWAPNIL: They like
SWAPNIL: Burnt them. Some of them, anyway. It gets cold up here. And I
SWAPNIL: had to make the pattern stand out.
DOCTOR: Why are the black squares metal? Why not just paint the wood?
SWAPNIL: So I can play in the dark after lights out. You can feel the metal under your feet. The cold ones are black, the warm ones are white. I take it you’ve recovered now, Doctor, after your
SWAPNIL: accident?
DOCTOR: Which one? I’m having them hourly.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 60
SWAPNIL: Avalanche. French windows.
DOCTOR: I pick myself up, brush myself down, and start all over again. How did you make the pieces, Swapnil? They’re hefty things.
SWAPNIL: Ah, there I did have help. I carved them all myself — but Mrs Kniddel dragged the logs up the side of the mountain.
DOCTOR: Mate in two moves, I see.
SWAPNIL: Poppycock.
DOCTOR: Yes. Look. You don’t need to be Capablanca to work it out.
HARRY: Losing your touch, Swapnil?
SWAPNIL: Never.
DOCTOR: Yes, look, I’1l show you. Let’s bring this bishop down here. (FX: LIFTS PIECE AND PLONKS IT DOWN.) Oh, they’re lighter than they look.
SWAPNIL: To which I must respond by protecting my queen.
DOCTOR: To which the only logical reply is bishop takes pawn. Checkmate.
DOCTOR: (FX: HE MOVES THE PIECE. LOUD CRACKLE OF ELECTRICITY. DOCTOR FALLS TO THE FLOOR. )
HARRY: You’ve nobbled him, Swapnil.
HERBERT: What did you do?
SWAPNIL: I didn’t do anything.
SWAPNIL: (FX: FURIOUS SCUFFLING BEHIND THE WALL. THE DUMMY IS MOVING
LOUDLY: THROUGH THE WALLSPACE. )
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 61
HARRY: There’s that sound again. Like in the trenches. Scratting about under the duckboards.
HERBERT: Vermin, is it?
SWAPNIL: Sounds to me as if it’s escaped from its trap.
HARRY: Right. That settles it.
HERBERT: Settles what, Harry?
HARRY: I’m off to my room.
HERBERT: What for?
HARRY: To get my gun, old fellow.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 62
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 25: INT. HALLWAY
LUDO: Damn!
LUDO: (FX: SEVERAL MORE FOOTSTEPS. A FRUIT BOWL AND A BOX OF DRAUGHTS
ARE: TOPPLED. )
LUDO: Blast!
QUEENIE: (DISTRESSED) Doctor Comfort, I need your help.
LUDO: Eh?
QUEENIE: Er... why do you have a scarf tied over your eyes?
LUDO: They said it couldn’t be done. And they were right. You can’t play blind man’s buff on your own. (FX: SCARF UNTIED) Still, it was an interesting experiment. That’s better. Hello, Mrs Glasscock.
QUEENIE: I need your help. The Doctor — he’s been thrown down the mountain by an avalanche. He went right through a pair of French windows.
LUDO: Oh, so that’s the noise was.
SWAPNIL: (ENTERING) .. never you fear, it’s all been seen to, my petal. The Doctor is quite alright. Just having a little lie down in the director’s study.
QUEENIE: Then I'd better go and see him.
SWAPNIL: He’s fast asleep.
LUDO: (EXITING) Don’t worry. I’1ll go and look in on him. And if I’ve any concerns, I’1ll inform you immediately.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 63
SWAPNIL: He’s a good man, Queenie.
QUEENIE: He’s a lunatic, Daddy. When I came in here he was playing blind man’s buff on his own...
SWAPNIL: Why are there apples all over the floor?
QUEENIE: Daddy, why don’t we leave this dreadful place? If we go back to the cable car maybe we can return to Davos. Book in somewhere there.
SWAPNIL: No, my love. Can’t be done.
QUEENIE: But what’s happening here, daddy?
SWAPNIL: I hate to say this — because my father used to say it to me — but there are some questions that are better left unasked, my little fruit bat.
SWAPNIL: (FX: A BANGING AND A SCUFFLING BEHIND THE WALL. THE DUMMY IS ON
ITS: WAY AGAIN, LOOKING FOR A WAY OUT.)
QUEENIE: What in heaven’s name is that, Daddy?
SWAPNIL: And that’s one of them.
QUEENIE: One of what?
SWAPNIL: One of those questions.
SWAPNIL: (FX: BANG BANG BANG FROM BEHIND THE WALL. AND A KNOCK KNOCK KNOCK ON THE FRONT DOOR. )
SWAPNIL: Great Scott! There’s two of them!
QUEENIE: That’s the front door, Daddy. I’d best get it —
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 64
QUEENIE: Oh. It’s you. What do you want?
LOLA: Fun, meine liebling...
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 65
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 26: INT. ATTIC
LOLA: (FX: OVER ROBOT’S SCREEN) .. Isn’t that what every girl wants?
ACE: He’s behind the wall in the hallway.
HEX: But what’s he trying to do?
ACE: Find a way out.
HEX: Well at least we know he can’t just kick through the plaster.
ACE: But he’s bound to show himself soon. And when he does — when the Doctor clocks him — and if the others see him, too...
HEX: It’s all going to go mental.
ACE: More mental.
HEX: Okay, so let’s cut off some of his escape routes. The cable car.
ACE: I’1l send the robot out to disable it.
HEX: Ace — is this what it’s like being the Doctor?
ACE: What do you mean?
HEX: Being the one who knows what’s going on, but can’t say what it is. Being the one with the masterplan — and not knowing whether it’s going to work out, or send the universe down the plughole...
ACE: Maybe it is. How do you like it?
HEX: It’s doing my head in.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 66
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 27: INT. GAMES ROOM
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: DOOR OPENS AND SWAPNIL, LUDO, QUEENIE AND MRS KNIDDEL ENTER. )
LOLA: What about a game of happy families? The cards are all here. Something to take our minds off it all. Mrs Kniddel, set them up! Let’s sit down, shall we?
LOLA: (FX: MRS KNIDDEL DEALS THE CARDS. SCRAPE OF CHAIRS AT THE CARD TABLE. )
SWAPNIL: I think it’s too late for that, Miss Luna.
SWAPNIL: (FX: A SCRAPING SOUND FROM BEHIND THE WALL. THE DUMMY IS ATTEMPTING TO SCRATCH ITS WAY THROUGH THE PLASTER. )
LOLA: Nonsense.
QUUENIE: It’s following us from room to room.
SWAPNIL: He. It’s a him.
LOLA: Come, let’s play.. (FX: FLICK OF CARDS) Mrs Kniddel, do you have Master Tape the Tailor’s Son?
QUEENIE: You know him, don’t you?
SWAPNIL: I used to know him. But the electric shocks, you know. They cured me of all that.
QUEENIE: Did I ever know him, daddy?
SWAPNIL: No. I kept you out of it.
QUEENIE: He’s moved again. He’s behind the wainscot. By the door to the balcony...
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 67
SWAPNIL: He is looking for a weak spot in the plasterwork.
QUEENIE: Who put him there?
SWAPNIL: I did. And Ludo. And you, too Lola.
LOLA: Swapnil...
SWAPNIL: And all the others. We brought him here. To Hahlbruck. A safe, cold, lonely place.
LOLA: Swapnil, you must not remember.
QUEENIE: But who is he?
SWAPNIL: I can’t remember.
QUEENIE: Is it Dr Black? Is that who it is? Dr Black bricked up behind the wall. Not dead. Just hidden away.
SWAPNIL: I mustn’t remember. Otherwise it’s checkmate. So no more questions, Queenie. I’ve said too much.
HERBERT: (ENTERING) Yes I think you have.
HARRY: (ENTERING) What are you talking about, you two?
SWAPNIL: Harry...
HARRY: I said what are you talking about?
HERBERT: I’d answer the question if I were you.
LOLA: Is that gun loaded, Harry?
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 68
QUEENIE: (FX: KNOCKING ON WALL) Hello?
SWAPNIL: Queenie, don’t.
QUEENIE: Hello, can you hear me? I’m fed up of all this. I want some answers. One knock for yes and two knocks for no.
SWAPNIL: Don’t talk to him, Queenie.
QUEENIE: Do you mean us any harm?
HARRY: Stop that!
QUEENIE: Do you mean the Doctor any harm?
LOLA: He’s replying to her!
HARRY: I’m warning you, Mrs Glasscock!
QUEENIE: Are you trying to get out?
HERBERT: My brother is pointing a gun in your direction, Queenie.
QUEENIE: Can you get out?
SWAPNIL: Be quiet, Queenie.
LOLA: Stop her, Harry!
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 69
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 28: INT. LUDO’S STUDY
DOCTOR: What was that?
LUDO: Harry, I think.
DOCTOR: Nice couch you’ve put me on. This is your consulting room, I take it?
LUDO: Correct.
DOCTOR: Oh. Tell me the worst, then. What are you? Jungian? Kleinian?
LUDO: Freudian, actually.
DOCTOR: I’m sure it’s what Mother would have wanted.
LUDO: Mother was a patient of Charcot at the Salpetriere in Paris. She performed her hysteria for him twice a day. Rolled her eyes and shrugged herself out of her negligee. The students went wild for her. She was the Sarah Bernhardt of mental pathology.
DOCTOR: (YAWNS) Fascinating.
LUDO: May I remind you, Doctor, that I am sitting in the alienist’s chair and you are the one in the recumbent posture.
DOCTOR: Oh, do you mean you’re the one who’s asking the questions?
LUDO: Look, Doctor, whatever you may think, I’m not your enemy. I’m trying to make things better.
DOCTOR: I’ll believe that when I start to feel better.
LUDO: Do you remember how you came here?
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 70
DOCTOR: By cable car. With Mrs Queenie Glasscock. Recently married but more recently jilted. By a man from the Herne Hill velodrome. And he seemed so nice. I hope you’re writing all of this down.
DOCTOR: (FX: A DRY SCUFFLE. THE DUMMY IS SCRABBLING ITS WAY TOWARDS A
POSSIBLE: EXIT.)
DOCTOR: What was that?
LUDO: What’s your first memory of your parents?
DOCTOR: Perhaps we should deal with my friends, first.
DOCTOR: What is that noise?
LUDO: Your friends?
DOCTOR: Ace. And the other one. Scouse lad. We were talking to them both last night. Only they were behaving rather strangely. Like everybody else here. And that’s because you’re all part of a conspiracy.
LUDO: Really, Doctor, this is textbook paranoia. You’1ll be telling me next that people are staring at you on trams.
DOCTOR: I didn’t come to Switzerland for my health, Doctor Comfort. I was lured here, wasn’t I? I’ve put my foot in some sort of trap, and you’re keeping me inside it with electric shocks and morphine. But it’s stopped working. I’m learning to resist. I think I know who I am. Did you mother love you, Ludo?
LUDO: She wanted to, Doctor. She wanted to.
LUDO: (FX: THE NOISE IS CLOSER — THE DUMMY HAS SQUEEZED ITS WAY FROM THE WALLSPACE INTO A BUILT-IN CUPBOARD. A CHINK OF BOTTLES. )
DOCTOR: Do you think, Doctor Comfort, that there might be a rodent in your medicine cabinet?
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 71
LUDO: Rats love Switzerland. All the cheese, you know.
DOCTOR: And you lay poison for them, do you?
LUDO: Yes we do.
DOCTOR: But they’re clever little creatures, rats. They learn to ignore the bait. They learn that behind the wainscot, there’s no such thing as a free lunch. They learn to bite back.
DOCTOR: Who’s in the cabinet, Ludo?
LUDO: Nobody.
DOCTOR: It’s not your mother, is it?
LUDO: No.
DOCTOR: Who, then? A patient?
LUDO: I don’t know. I’ve heard the noise from time to time. I’ve never dared to look.
DOCTOR: Why?
LUDO: Doctor, the more you discover, the more you put us all in danger.
DOCTOR: Ludo, in the past fifteen hours or so I’ve been caught up in an avalanche. I’ve been drugged. I’ve received two electric shocks of considerable ferocity. I want to know why. I’m going to open the cupboard.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL)
LUDO: Please, Doctor...!
DOCTOR: Get your hands off me, Ludo.
LUDO: Don’t do it!
DOCTOR: Well, that isn’t what I expected.
LUDO: No.
DOCTOR: Did you know this was here?
LUDO: No.
DOCTOR: You’re not a friend of this little wooden man?
LUDO: No.
DOCTOR: You don’t do a ventriloquist act as your party piece?
LUDO: No.
DOCTOR: Then why is he here?
LUDO: And who is he?
DOCTOR: Page 72
DOCTOR: Ludo — his name — it’s just come into my head. Like someone
DOCTOR: lifting a curtain.
LUDO: His mouth, Doctor. He’s going to speak.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 73
DOCTOR: Hello. Are you who I think you are? Are you the Toymaker? The Celestial Toymaker?
DUMMY: Gockleageer... Doc-tor!
DUMMY: END OF PART TWO
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 74

elements.text: PART THREE
SCENE CONTINUES:
SCENE 29: INT. LUDO’S STUDY
LUDO and DOCTOR
Did you do that?
LUDO and DOCTOR
No.
Certainly not.
It was him. It. That little man.
How can you be the Celestial Toymaker? You’re just wood and papier mache. (SILENCE) Lost your tongue, have you?
I’ve heard the name before. In a novel, perhaps? The Celestial Toymaker. Who is he? A sort of Fu Manchu?
He’s from the Old Times. A spirit of mischief from the infancy of the universe.
I take it you’re recovering from your aphasic episode, then?
I know who I am. I know who he is. I know who the people in the attic are. But who are you, Ludo? Who are you? And what are we all doing here?

Before you blew up the machine, Doctor, I used to self- administer a little dose of electricity. Just before I went to bed each night. It cleared my head, that little dose of electricity. Allowed me to get a good night’s sleep. I didn’t get my medicine last night. By the end of today, I may be able to answer your question.
Ludo, there’s something else you should know about the Toymaker.
What?
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 75
He likes games.
So he’s a jolly sort of chap then, is he?
If he wins.
It’s the same with all children, Doctor.
Children tend not to kill their opponents if they beat them at snakes and ladders.
Did it sound familiar to you, Doctor? The voice?
Why do you ask, Ludo?
For a moment I wondered if —
(DISTANTLY) Aaaaaaaargh!
Queenie!
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 76
SCENE 30: INT. GAMES ROOM
FX: A CARD GAME IN PROGRESS.
(FX: A WHISTLE OF COMMISERATION THROUGH HER PNEUMOTHORACIC TUBE) Ah, bad luck, Mrs Kniddel1!
Miss Luna, do you have Master Bun the Baker’s Son?
I am pleased to say, that he is not among my Buns. Harry — do you have Mrs Dose, the Doctor’s Wife?
I do, sweetheart. And I must yield her.
Feeling better, Harry? Now you’ve let off a bit of steam?
I’ve a game to concentrate on, haven’t I?
FX: FLICK OF CARDS
I wonder if she’s alright? Mrs Glasscock, I mean.
Don’t think I went too far, do you?
What do you think, Swapnil? You stood by and watch it happen.
Yes, well, I had my reasons. I lost control for a moment. And I said too much. And she asked too much. She would have endangered us all if someone hadn’t stopped her.
Herbert — do you have the Doctor himself? Herr Dose?
Not me, Miss Luna.
I’m simply happy that she’s out of the game...
(FX: DOCTOR THROWS OPEN THE DOOR. HARRY AND HERBERT JUMP TO THEIR FEET. )
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 77
Where is she?
For the moment, at least.
(MARCHING FORWARD) Where is she?!
Fell out of the window, darling. Gazing at the moonlight on the snow. And out she tumbled. Over the balustrade. What is the word?
Defenestrated!
Defenestrated. Danke!
Swapnil, what’s going on?
I’m just trying to keep out of it all, really, old chum. And to keep Queenie out of it, too.
Let me pass, gentlemen. I need to get to that balcony.
Harry. Herbert. Stand aside. Let’s get back to our game.
Thank-you.
FX: HE THROWS OPEN THE WINDOW
Queenie! Queenie! Can you hear me?
(FROM DOWN BELOW) Doctor!
Queenie, are you alright?
(FROM DOWN BELOW) I’m not dead, if that’s what you mean, Doctor. Wonderful things, snowdrifts.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page
Stay put. I’m coming to get you.
(FROM DOWN BELOW) Right-ho.
Is the dear girl unhurt?
No thanks to you, Swapnil.
You must think me an irresponsible parent, Doctor.
Discuss it with your analyst, Swapnil, not me.
FX: HE STORMS OUT OF THE ROOM.
Mrs Kniddel — you have Mr Dose the Doctor! Put him on the table. Where we can see him.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 79
SCENE 31: INT. THE ATTIC
FX: TAP AT ATTIC DOOR
(MUFFLED BY THE DOOR) Will you let me in, please?
FX: ELECTRIC BEEP OF ATTIC DOOR; WHOOSH OF DOOR OPENING.
Evening, Ludo.
The gloves are off. Someone’s pushed Queenie out of the window.
You were right, Hex. Things are starting to go mental.
We’re gonna have a murder before tea.
I fear you’re right. It’s the Doctor’s influence. He knows about someone named the Toymaker.
Oh yeah?
He’s the one behind all this, isn’t he? Isn’t he? The Celestial Toymaker.
Well...
He’s like a puzzle in my head that’s slowly being solved. Like a crossword being filled in.
Just don’t think about it, Ludo.
Does the Doctor know about us? Does he know who we are?
So he says.
Okay. And where is this dummy now?
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 80
In my consulting room.
Let’s have a dekko. (FX: HEX SWITCHES ON THE ROBOT’S SCANNER. )
BEAT
It’s vanished!
Must have gone for a walk.
It could be anywhere in the clinic. Watching us.
Ludo!
Come on, guys, we need an idea here. Something to distract the patients.
