HERBERT: Venus in Thirsk.
HERBERT: HARRY. Venus in Thirsk?
HERBERT: In all her natural glory.
HARRY: Picturesque?
HERBERT: From up there you can see five counties.
HARRY: I wouldn’t know where to look.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 101
LOLA: What are they talking about?
SWAPNIL: I haven’t the faintest notion.
LOLA: (CALLING OUT) I thought you boys were tumblers.
HARRY: We are, Miss.
HERBERT: He’s half full.
HARRY: And he’s half empty.
HERBERT: Give us a few chords, Miss Kniddell! Let’s roll out the barrels.
HARRY: To you, Herbert!
HERBERT: Hup-la!
HERBERT: To me, Harry!
HARRY: Hupp-la!
HERBERT: Hupp-laaaa!
SWAPNIL: I didn’t know Harry could jump like that.
LOLA: Mein Gott. They are so agile.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 102
LOLA: Bravo!
HEX: (AS BOBO)
HEX: Extraordinary. Our next act is, as they say in the jolly old mill towns, flaming marvellous! May I present Mrs Queenie Glasscock — the female Prometheus!
SWAPNIL: Where is she?
HERBERT: What’s happened to her?
DOCTOR: (FX: LEAPING TO THE STAGE) Never fear, everybody!
HEX: (AS BOBO) Please take your seat, sir.
DOCTOR: I have another idea. Let me entertain you!
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 103
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 39: EXT. CABLE CAR PLATFORM/INT. CABLE CAR
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: QUEENIE IS RUNNING THROUGH THE SNOW AS FAST AS SHE CAN, CLUTCHING A BAG. )
ACE: (AS BUNTY) (FOLLOWING) Queenie! Queenie, stop!
QUEENIE: Not likely!
ACE: (AS BUNTY)
ACE: I know what you’re planning. The cable car won’t work. It’s been sabotaged. And anyway, it doesn’t go to Davos. It’ll just bring you back here.
QUEENIE: (FX: COMING TO A HALT) I’m not planning to go to Davos. I hate Davos.
ACE: (AS HERSELF — SHE’S FORGETTING TO KEEP THE ACCENT UP) Then what are you up to?
QUEENIE: Well that’s between me and the contents of this carpet bag.
QUEENIE: Obliging, aren’t they? You just stand near it and it all starts
QUEENIE: ups
ACE: Don’t get on it, Queenie.
QUEENIE: What happened to your Roedean vowels, Mrs Stetterton?
ACE: Just don’t get on it.
QUEENIE: Too late!
QUEENIE: (FX: SHE JUMPS ON BOARD, AND SLAMS THE DOOR. THE CAR BEGINS TO MOVE. )
ACE: I’m coming to get you out of there, Queenie!
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 104
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: ACE JUMPS TOWARDS THE CABLE CAR AND WRENCHES OPEN THE DOOR. )
QUEENIE: You’re insane!
ACE: Insane enough to jump into a moving cable car, yeah. Particularly as I asked the robot to put them out of action. Maybe he just forgot.
QUEENIE: There was a girl like you on the bicycling team. Mad Fanny we called her. Calves like flitches of bacon. No sense of danger.
ACE: Let’s have a look in the bag, Queenie. Come on.
QUEENIE: Alright.
QUEENIE: (FX: QUEENIE OPENS THE BAG. SHE PULLS OUT A MILK BOTTLE FULL OF PETROL WITH A RAG FUSE. A CHINK OF GLASS. )
ACE: Hey, that’s a Molotov Cocktail!
QUEENIE: A firebomb, I think you mean.
ACE: Yeah, but what are you going to do with it?
QUEENIE: Burn down the sky, of course.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 105
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 40: INT. GAMES ROOM
DOCTOR: You may be wondering, ladies and gentlemen, what lurks inside my trunk.
HEX: (AS BOBO) Take it easy, Doctor.
DOCTOR: All of you are being kept here against your will — Swapnil, Mrs Kniddel, Harry, Herbert, Lola. You, Hex. And Queenie and Ace, too, wherever they are.
HEX: Please, just for once in your life, leave it alone.
DOCTOR: What do you think, ladies and gentlemen? Should I keep quiet, or open the box?
LOLA: Open the box.
DOCTOR: Thank you, Miss Luna.
LUDO: Don’t do it, Doctor!
DOCTOR: Dr Comfort — I’d almost forgotten that you were here. Having fun?
HARRY: We want to see what’s inside, don’t we Herbert?
HERBERT: We do, Harry. What about you, Swapnil?
SWAPNIL: Oh, I don’t know. It’s just a box.
DOCTOR: The box, I agree, is nothing special. It’s what’s inside that counts.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 106
HARRY: What the blazes is that, Herbert?
HERBERT: It’s a mechanical man.
DOCTOR: Glad you could make it. What do you think, little robot?
ROBOT: Open the box.
DOCTOR: Very well.
HERBERT: A dummy. A vent’s dummy.
LUDO: You don’t know what you’re doing, Doctor. Oh Lord, it’s happening. I’m remembering him. I’m finally remembering him.
DOCTOR: Allow me to introduce an old enemy.
LOLA: I remember him too.
HARRY: The Toymaker.
HERBERT: The Celestial Toymaker.
HARRY: We did for him, didn’t we, Herbert? The old Chinese mandarin.
LOLA: He thought that he could control us, but he was wrong. It can see it all happening, like a film running in my head. He brought us to his world.
SWAPNIL: And he made us play games.
HARRY: So many games. Things we’d never heard of.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 107
LUDO: But we challenged him. We challenged him to play all those games simultaneously. Slaves against the master.
LOLA: I remember our moment of victory. He threw up his hands in horror. And the playing cards blew up around him. Like Alice in Wonderland. And after it was over — he’d turned into that thing. That doll.
HERBERT: We overpowered him together.
LOLA: He was a mandarin.
SWAPNIL: So we divided him into segments, and each ate one up.
HERBERT: And we came back here to recover, didn’t we, Harry? We all came to Hahlbruck for a good old rest. Put our feet up for a bit. Why couldn’t I remember this yesterday?
LUDO: We each held a little piece of him in our heads. So we came here to Hahlbruck — my alma mater — and we used the ECT machine to keep him confined in our unconscious minds. Because if we couldn’t remember he was there...
LOLA: Then he couldn’t escape. And we would keep him in his place. Keep him beaten. Until he was no more.
DOCTOR: You beat the Toymaker? A bunch of humans beat the Toymaker and brought him home to earth? In pieces? It’s ridiculous! It’s impossible.
LUDO: Impossible, yes. On our own. But we had help, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Help from whom?
LUDO: From you, Doctor.
DOCTOR: From me?
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 108
LUDO: And from your friends. Mr and Mrs Stetterton.
DOCTOR: From Hex and Ace.
HEX: You’ve really stuffed this one up, Doctor. All we needed was a couple more hours and the Toymaker would have withered away.
DOCTOR: Hex, what’s happening?
HEX: It was your plan, Doctor. You set all this up. A hundred games at once, just like you always do. So tell us — what do we do now?
DOCTOR: I don’t know. I’ve played against myself.
DUMMY: And lost, Doctor!
DOCTOR: Ah. So you found your voice again, have you? You’ve found someone’s voice, certainly —
DUMMY: Pull back the curtain, Mrs Kniddel. (FX: CURTAIN IS PULLED. ) All of you — look out of the window. The cable car.
LOLA: It’s moving.
HEX: It can’t be moving. Me and Ace had it shut down.
LOLA: Who’s on board?
DOCTOR: Queenie. It must be Queenie.
SWAPNIL: (ODDLY UNCONCERNED) Yes, I suppose it must be.
DUMMY: Not only her. The Honourable Mrs Bunty Stetterton also.
HEX: Oh my God.
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 109
DUMMY: A string of diamonds across the neck of the mountain... I wonder
DUMMY: what would happen if that string were to snap?
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 110
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 41: INT. CABLE CAR.
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: THE CABLE CAR GRINDS ON... QUEENIE IS FIDDLING WITH A RAG
STUCK: INTO THE NECK OF A BOTTLE OF PETROL. )
ACE: Burning stuff never achieved anything, Queenie. Trust me on this.
QUEENIE: We’ll see.
ACE: All your firebomb’s gonna do is melt some snow. It won’t help any of the others. It won’t help your dad.
QUEENIE: Not like you’ve been helping him, with electric shocks. (FX:
STRIKES: MATCH; LIGHTS FUSE) What a beauty! Out of the window you must go!
STRIKES: (FX: THE CABLE CAR GRINDS TO A HALT. THE LIGHTS SIZZLE AND FAIL. )
QUEENIE: What happened to the lights? Shall I strike a match?
ACE: No. Don’t strike anything. This could be very bad.
ACE: (FX: METAL CABLES TWIST AND SNAG. THE CABLE CAR LURCHES. _
QUEENIE: What’s happening?
ACE: That robot must have done what we asked it to. It’s the cable. It’s going to [snap —]
ACE: (FX: BUT WE DON’T HEAR THE LAST WORDS: THE STEEL CORDS GIVE WAY, THE FALLS FROM ITS HOUSING. BUT WE CUT AWAY SHARPISH — NO LINGERING ON ANY FALL INTO THE ABYSS.)
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 111
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 42: INT. BALLROOM
SWAPNIL: Queenie. And the other one. Are they [dead]?
DOCTOR: What did you do?
DUMMY: Nothing. But they’re out of the game, all the same. Permanently out of the game.
DUMMY: END OF PART THREE
DOCTOR WHO: THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 112

elements.text: PART FOUR
SCENE CONTINUES:
SCENE 43: INT. BALLROOM

Oh no! We’re not going through this again. I spent ten years trapped in your domain, Toymaker. A decade of electric-shock tiddlywinks and poison-tipped pin the tail on the donkey. Do you think I could go back to that madness?
(FX: LUDO LUNGES FOR THE DUMMY AND PICKS HIM UP BY THE SCRUFF OF HIS NECK.)
Put the dummy down, Ludo.
Absolutely not. A funny thing happened to me on the way to the ballroom. I noticed there was an axe inside the piano. Mrs Kniddel, pass it to me, please.
FX: MRS KNIDDEL PULLS THE AXE FROM THE PIANO.
Looks good and sharp. And we were running low on firewood.
Ludo, stop! You can’t just chop him up!
(HEFTS THE AXE — EFFORT) Here we go. Three, two, [one —]
HALTS, GAGS — THE DUMMY STEALING HIS VOICE
Ludo, darling. What is wrong-?
(STRANGULATED, STRUGGLING TO GET WORDS OUT) My voice. It — (CUT SHORT)
A direct attack on a fellow player is against the rules, Ludo.
Doctor...?
Yes. The dummy has stolen his voice.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 113
(GASPING) No! No more of the madness-! (SWINGING AXE) Hah-!
FX: A DULL THUD
. So you feel the blow, not me. And restore to me what is rightfully mine.
FX: A STRANGE PULSE OF ENERGY. THE AXE CLATTERS TO THE FLOOR
What —
. what just happened?
Ludo broke the rules.
And forfeited his place in the game.
Now he’s just a little wooden alienist. Mrs Kniddel, put him in the box, please. (FX: WOODEN CLUNK) Lose against me, and I take back what you stole. A little gobbet of my consciousness.
How many do you have now? How many pieces of pie?
Just Ludo’s share.
Excellent. Then Queenie and Ace must still be alive.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 114
SCENE 44: EXT. CABLE CAR
(FX: METALLIC CREAKS; THE CABLE CAR HAS HIT THE GROUND; THE
CRACKLING OF FIRE.)
(SLIGHTLY DAZED) Queenie...
Mrs Glasscock to you.
You knew that would happen, didn’t you?
I was more or less certain.
I felt the car bounce. How totally weird.
We’1ll need to walk back now. Across the sky.
FX: THE DOOR CREAKS OPEN.
Door still works, then.
FX: THEY CLAMBER OUT. THEIR FEET HIT CANVAS.
There’s the cable. What’s left of it.
We can only have been a foot off the ground. Except that this isn’t the ground.
No. It’s canvas. Painted canvas. The stars are under our feet.
Lovely job, though, isn’t it? Even from the window, it looked real.
And now we can walk across it.
But when you and the Doctor were caught up in the avalanche...
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 115
We walked up the mountain and then came down. We didn’t go any lower in the valley than the cable car station.
There’s a light up ahead.
FX: DISTANT CRACKLE OF FIRE.
What is it?
That’s your Molotov cocktail burning up the canvas.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 116
SCENE 45: EXT. BALLROOM
What happened to you, Toymaker? You used to be much taller.

I concede it. All my opponents — loser after loser after loser — were turned into dolls and packed away in my toybox. And then I lost. And now my eyes are two glass beads strung on a wire. My legs are pieces of wood with a hinge where my hyperdimensional knees should be. And yet I know your desires. And I can satisfy them. Miss Luna!
Yes?

There’s a little piece of me in you, Miss Luna. And it’s stirring up such thoughts, isn’t it? You’d like the doctors to pluck that pneumothoracic tube from your addled lung. You’d like to hit all the high notes in Lili Marlene. And to sing again in your own little club.
It would be divine.

And you can have it. You can have it all. If you play along. Here’s what I intend. You will take on each other in games of my choosing. And when we have one victor, one winner, one player triumphant...
Ja?
I will sit on their knee. And give them what they want.
Don’t listen to him, Lola. He’s only made of wood.
Miss Luna — whom do you choose as your first opponent?
I choose Mrs Kniddel. Sorry, Elsa.
And I choose the game. You’1ll have to give me a moment to conjure up the hardware. My psychosynthetic powers are not what they once were.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 117
FX: THE WEIRD SOUND OF THE TOYMAKER CONJURING SOMETHING UP.
Hang on loose and we’ll be back in a deuce.
(SOTTO) What’s that?
(SOTTO) A game show set. Being condensed from the ether. And our cue to slip away, Mr Schofield. Let’s go up to your little hidey-hole in the attic.
(FX: THEY OPEN THE DOOR AND THEN SHUT IT BEHIND THEM. THE
SOUND CONTINUES. )
Now that’s what I call a scene change.
(SOTTO) Do you think he noticed [the Doctor —]?
. the Doctor, and his chunky young friend? Of course I did. But the Doctor’s not in this round. So let’s play.
FX: FLOURISH OF GAMESHOW MUSIC FROM THE ROBOT’S SPEAKER.
Easy one, this. I’m going to pose a question based on one of our surveys. All you have to do is answer it. Miss Luna, I believe you won the toss.
TL did ¢
Then you can begin. We asked 100 teachers, has a pupil ever given you an apple? Miss Luna, how many said yes?
Erm.
How many of the teachers we surveyed said they had been in receipt of that most attractive fruit?
Twenty-four.
Twenty-four. Now, Mrs Kniddel, is the true answer higher or lower? What do you think, boys?
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 118
Higher?
Lower?
Higher.
Thanks boys. Mrs Kniddel. Just point up or down, there’s a love. (SHE DOES SO.) Higher you say? Let’s see, shall we? Robot! Reveal the legend!
FX: APPROPRIATE NEGATIVE GAMESHOW SOUND FROM THE ROBOT.
What a clever little automaton.
It was lower. The actual number of teachers who said they’d received this juicy little gift was fifteen. So, Mrs Kniddel, that means that you get the first electric shock. 200 volts. Robot!
FX: BUZZ AND CRACKLE. A GENERAL WINCE.
And still she remains silent. But will she stay that way? Because there’s another shock on its way — Miss Luna, will the
next voltage be higher or lower?
HARRY AND HERBERT AND SWAPNIL Lower! Lower!
Higher. Definitely higher!
Let’s give it a whirl.
FX: POSITIVE CHIME
You were right. Five hundred volts!
FX: CRACKLE AND BUZZ
He’s killed her.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 119
Not yet. Higher or lower, Miss Luna?
Higher.
(FX: POSITIVE CHIME, THEN A CRACKLE. MRS KNIDDEL SCREAMS. A
CLUNK. )
Elsa... a little doll.
Put her in the toybox, Swapnil. I think we have a winner. Miss Luna, I’m going to sit on your knee.
FX: A STRANGE SURGE OF ENERGY.
There, that wasn’t so bad, was it?
Nein, nein!
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 120
SCENE 46: INT. ATTIC
So, Mr Schofield, tell me what I’ve missed.
You’re unbelievable sometimes, you know that.
Tell me what happened. Then perhaps we can get back to the ballroom and stop any more of it happening. This is where you were hiding? Your little robot’s gone, I see.
You had it all worked out, didn’t you? New identities to stop
all the patients remembering us. Bringing the Toymaker back to the clinic. Keeping everybody in the dark long enough for his
powers to fail.
The Toymaker can’t survive for long outside his world. It might have worked.

And it did work. The Toymaker pulled the TARDIS into his world and forced us to play his games. But we organised a revolution. We all played against him. And the Toymaker lost. His body turned into a toy — just like one of his victims.
But how did we get the Toymaker to Earth?
That was easy. We just clicked our fingers, like he does. Used a little bit of that power.
Who clicked their fingers?
Ludo did. It was his idea to use the clinic as a hiding place. A place where a bit of craziness wouldn’t be noticed.
So everyone has a splinter of the Toymaker lodged in his or her mind... I can feel him in my head, scuttering about. A rat in the skull.
No wonder they’re all nuts.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 121
But he’s not in you or in Ace. Is he?

No. You put us in charge. To make sure you all got your juice — so you wouldn’t remember. So we could keep track of the time until all those pieces of the Toymaker just broke down. That was Plan A. But now he’s sticking himself back together again.
And what about Queenie?
What about her?
I think she exists outside this, too.
I dunno about her.
Can I smell burning?
Open the skylight.
FX: THE DOCTOR PUSHES IT OPEN.
It’s the sky, Hex. It’s on fire.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 122
SCENE 47: INT. BALLROOM
FX: THE DISTANT SOUND OF BURNING CANVAS.
Looks a picture, doesn’t it? The clouds peeling away from the air.
The world is just one big cyclorama.
We’re not really on a mountain at all. It’s like a stage set.
A huge sheet of canvas.
A huge sheet of burning canvas.
What does it all mean? What do you think, Lola?
I don’t know. I’m a little distracted. Mrs Kniddel has turned into a German doll and there’s a little wooden man sitting on my knee.
You've inherited Mrs Kniddel’s share of the my power, Miss Luna. How does it feel?
Interesting.
Just imagine, Lola, what it would be like to hold all the cards.
Exhilarating, darling, I suspect.
Little dummy — isn’t the burning sky a more pressing problem?
I don’t think so. Now. Harry and Herbert!
HARRY and HERBERT Yes?
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 123
You’re in with a chance as we play — What’s my Punchline!
What’s my what?
FX: FLOURISH OF MUSIC
Fingers on buzzers please. I wouldn’t say my mother-in-law was fat, but...
FX: BUZZ
Harry?
She has a dysfunction of the pituitary gland.
FX: GAMESHOW RASPBERRY
Sorry, Harry. Do you know it, Miss Luna?
Actually, I think I do.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 124
SCENE 48: INT. ATTIC
FX: DISTANT CRACKLING.
What’s causing it? Some kind of gas, maybe?
No. The sky is not the sky. The sky is canvas.
We didn’t move at all, did we? When Ludo clicked his fingers. It never worked.
No. This is still his Celestial Toyroom.
So - out there, beyond that fire, there’s just white?
The Toymaker’s world is one of infinite possibilities. An empty dimension in which his will can fashion matter from nothingness.
So he didn’t whisk us all to Earth, he just recreated the clinic inside the Toymaker’s world.
A whole dimension, reconfigured into one building and its grounds.
But how could Ludo do all that on his own?
He didn’t. I’m responsible for some of it. Or my unconscious is. This is one of my own traps — I just don’t know how it works.

It works on electricity. Once all this was set up, we settled into the routine. Me and Ace stayed in the attic. Ludo made sure everybody got enough volts to keep them ignorant. Every day you and Queenie would come in on the cable car. Every day Herbert and Lola would do the same. Then you and Queenie would try to solve the mystery of who killed Dr Black.
And who did kill Dr Black?
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 125

Nobody. You were Dr Black. In the treatment room, with the ECT machine, giving yourself convulsions until your memory was blank. Every day you came, worked a bit out, and then had it wiped away by the machine. Then we stuck you back on the cable car and waited for you to arrive again.
Hex, there’s someone out there in the snow. Running away from the fire.
Who is it?
It’s Queenie. It’s Queenie Glasscock. And Ace.
We’d better go down and meet them.
Absolutely. Perhaps they have a Plan B.
FX: CLATTERING DOWN THE STAIRS.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 126
SCENE 49: INT. BALLROOM
I wouldn’t say this town was small, but the...
FX: BUZZ
Road signs are back to back.
FX: TING!
Lady goes into the greengrocers in the pouring rain. Asks for five pounds of onions. Says the greengrocer, “Are you pickling?”
FX: BUZZ!
“No, it’s my umbrella!”
FX: TING!
Who won the Irish woodcutting competition?
FX: BUZZ!
Tree fellers from Dublin.
FX: TING! LOUD RESONANT BONG.
Didn’t she do well? Now, Harry and Herbert. What happened? Those were your own jokes. That was your own material.
And we've all been here long enough for Miss Lola to learn it all.
Lovely timing, dear.
They’d love her at the Glasgow Empire, wouldn’t they? A funny German.
A novelty act.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 127
Herbert, you didn’t even try.
Don’t worry, Lola. It’s not such a tragedy.
You see, in 1914, I joined up. Went to France. Oh, I was dead patriotic in those days. Not like my brother.
Got the white feathers. So then I went. To be with my brother. And it was hell.
We’re twins, Miss Luna. But we’re not alike in every way.
You see, on my first leave back in Blighty I met a doctor ina room in the Regent Palace Hotel.
He had a little syringe.
Synovitis. One little prick and it was all over. The Great War. Unfit for service.
You’ve given us a second chance. A chance to go over the top together.
Old comics never die, do they?
No. We just fade away.
(FX: AS HARRY SPEAKS HIS WORDS FADE OUT WITH A SPOOKY SOUND EFFECT, WHICH IS IN TURN DROWNED OUT BY THE SOUND OF THE TARDIS MATERIALISING. )
What is that?
Ah! I was wondering when she’d turn up. I knew she was locked away inside someone’s head. Clever trick that — though I’ve seen it done before. Poor Harry. Wasn’t really the man for the job, was he?
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 128
SCENE 50: INT. THE GARDEN
FX: FLAMES
Ace!
Queenie! This way! You’1ll be fine once you reach the snow! (TO HEX) Amazing piece of work, isn’t it? A cyclorama wrapping up this building at the mountain peak. Some sky, some trees, some snow.
There won’t be much left soon.
(ARRIVING) Finished wrecking everything, have you?
Drop it, Ace.
Me wrecking everything! You’re the one who set fire to the sky.
That was me, actually, Doctor.
Well whoever it was, it’s revealed something very useful.
What? That you’ve screwed everything up?
That we are not in Switzerland. We’re not even in the Alps.
That we’ve all failed. That this trap for the Toymaker has been turned into a trap for us. If it was ever ours to set.
But the Toymaker lost. We saw it. Playing cards everywhere and him doing Jolson hands. We saw him break into pieces.
So what’s his game?
Daddy would know.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 129
Your daddy watched someone push you off the games room balcony, then played a game of Happy Families.
I know. But I’m here, aren’t I?
For the moment. But maybe none of us will be — after our next move. Right, Hex, Ace, Queenie. You want to hear Plan B? I’m afraid it’s terribly dangerous.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 130
SCENE 51: INT. GAMES ROOM
What should I do with these, Toymaker?
Put them in the box with the other toy soldiers.
Poor little boys. I’1l look after you. Put you out on Armistice Day.
How do you feel now, Lola?
Alright. I suppose.
Cheer up, Lola. Think what you’1ll be able to do when you've won.
Someone’s coming through the French windows.
FX: THE DOORS SWING OPEN.
Doctor!
Hello, everyone... I see you’ve brought back the TARDIS. Inside Harry’s mind, wasn’t it? What a party trick! How permeable everybody’s head is here...
Queenie, where have you been?
Setting fire to the sky, father. I just struck a match and up it went. Can you smell the burning paint? It was all a trick. We're not in Switzerland at all.
Yes, I worked it all out. We’re still in the Celestial Toyroom and I claim my prize.
What prize?
The right to play the next game.
THE MAGIC MOUSETRAP by Matthew Sweet (FINAL) Page 131
But it was Queenie who worked it out.
Err, well, yes.
The reward is hers.
Are you sure, Daddy?
Very well. You will play Miss Lola.
No, I forbid it!
Oh do stop it. What about a round of sudden death?
Actually we were hoping for something a bit more protracted.
How do you play?
You stand there, Miss Luna. And Mrs Glasscock, you stand there. Either side of my little robot. Who will then start the clock.
FX: A QUIET BUT INSISTENT TICKING.
And we listen. To this.
FX: TWO AMPLIFIED HEARTBEATS FROM THE ROBOT.
The sound of you hearts beating.
The tin man has a heart?
No. That’s yours, Mrs Glasscock...
